text: Business Entrepreneurship and Innovation Degree Program
Four Menlo College Students Named University Innovation Fellows by Stanford d.school Program

(Atherton, California/November 18, 2019) The University Innovation Fellows program empowers students to become agents of change at their schools. These student leaders are encouraged to increase campus engagement with innovation, entrepreneurship, creativity and design thinking. Fellows create student innovation spaces, start entrepreneurship organizations, facilitate experiential workshops, work with faculty and administrators to develop new courses, and much more. They serve as advocates for lasting institutional change with academic leaders, lending the much-needed student voice to the conversations about the future of higher education. The program is run by Stanford University’s Hasso Plattner Institute of Design (d.school). With the addition of this year’s new Fellows, the program has trained nearly 2,200 students.  Menlo College’s third cohort of fellows is represented by Bianca Barros ‘21, Christopher Overkämping ’21, George Hofstetter ’22 and  Rufus Pappy ‘22. The group has narrowed its priorities for the year to be centered around: enhancing the engagement of off-campus resources, creating more hands-on experiences for students, integrating more interdisciplinary business/socially-relevant general education courses and encouraging a more technologically literate community on campus.  “Higher education needs to change faster to meet the needs of students and industry today,” said Humera Fasihuddin, co-director of the University Innovation Fellows program. “In traditional education systems, students have to wait until they graduate to make a difference. We don’t believe that. As the key stakeholders of higher education, students should be active participants in a change process that helps them learn the skills and mindsets necessary to create the future. The students who participate in our program are ideally poised to help accelerate the pace of change at their schools.”   Contact: pr@menlo.edu...
Menlo College to Host Grow with Google Digital Skills Workshop

(Atherton, California/November 15, 2019) On November 20 from 12:45 p.m.-1:45 p.m., Google will be visiting the Menlo College campus to lead a digital skills workshop. The session, happening in the Russell Center, is free and open to the community. During this session, attendees will learn how to identify new job opportunities using Google Search, organize and enhance the job search experience using G Suite tools, complete an effective job search on Google, use Google Sheets to track the progress of job applications and create a resume using Google Docs.  The Digital Skills Workshop will be hosted by Roberto Martinez, a speaker for the Grow with Google partner program and a Google Digital Coach. Martinez has over 14 years of experience having led over 100 Google digital workshops. He runs his own digital marketing agency and advises various chambers, incubators, and accelerators on scaling companies using digital marketing tools.  All interested parties can RSVP to the event via this link.  About Menlo College  Founded in 1927, Menlo College is a small private four-year college with a mission to ignite potential and educate students to make meaningful contributions in the innovation economy. A residential college in the heart of Silicon Valley just outside San Francisco, Menlo College offers degrees in business and psychology. Our students come from all over the world to learn leadership, critical thinking, creativity, team building, communication and the science of behavior. We take advantage of the strong innovative community around us.  Students are required to take an internship at one of the many companies and incubators with which we have partnerships. We are proud of our intimate and engaged student community, fueled by our spirited and competitive athletics program.  More information about Menlo College can be found at www.menlo.edu.   Contact: pr@menlo.edu...
Record-Breaking Rise in Menlo College Enrollment

A record-breaking 35% rise in new students at Menlo College for the fall 2019 semester propelled enrollment to the highest enrollment ever.  The most recent incoming class is a standout for more reasons than the sheer growth it represents: other milestone achievements include an all-time high of 17 students who were the valedictorians of their high schools, a 3.35 overall high school grade point average, 24% minority student representation, and 31% first-generation student representation. Students are attracted to Menlo College from far and wide; they represent 29 states in this country and 38 other countries around the globe.   The record-setting enrollment at Menlo College stands in marked contrast to national trends in higher education. In 2019, national enrollment fell by 1.7%, with the most significant decline reported by the smallest schools. Reflecting strong forward momentum, Menlo College is continuing to see exceptional enrollment growth for the coming semester.  Menlo College’s President Steven A. Weiner said that  “Improvements in recruitment as well as retention contributed to the largest entering class and the largest total enrollment in the 92-year history of Menlo College. We celebrate this unprecedented success in attracting new students to Menlo as a reflection of the attention we garnered last year for the value of our small classes, engaged faculty and staff, and community feel.” He added that “We were helped in getting the word out about Menlo College by the extensive recognition we received for our programs last year. The quality of our education programs were heralded; we received an award from the state for the most innovative internship program; we landed among the top 1% of all schools in the country for the extent of our student diversity; we were ranked #1 in the state for school safety; and we ranked #1 in a study that was conducted to determine the school whose graduates secure the highest-paying jobs in the state.  The fact that Menlo Athletics secured two national titles last year was another well-earned boost to our reputation.”   Dean of Enrollment Management Priscila Casanova de Souza added that “Students and families are increasingly entrusting us with their education, career preparation, and well-being. They invest in a Menlo College degree because it is clear that the entire Menlo community is committed to supporting students in all aspects of their growth.”...
Menlo Adds Two Distinguished Professionals to its College Board of Trustees

(Atherton, California/September 19, 2019) – Menlo College is proud to announce that Helene Kim and Fran Schulz have been elected to serve as their newest Trustees. The new trustees will bring invaluable experience and advice to Menlo’s board.  Some background on the new trustees:  Helene Kim is an international lawyer and management strategy advisor based in San Francisco, and serves as an Adjunct Professor of Management at Menlo College.   She received her undergraduate degree (Summa Cum Laude) from Harvard-Radcliff College, and her JD from Harvard Law School.  After graduating from law school, she worked as a management strategy consultant for McKinsey Asia and as a business lawyer for Morrison & Foerster in San Francisco, then served as founding Executive Director of International & Executive Education and Lecturer in Residence at the University of California Berkeley.   Currently, she serves as a Director and Advisory Board Member of the Digital Cities research center at Stanford University.  Her community service includes roles as a founding member of the Seoul-San Francisco Sister City Committee; former Board Chair of the Korean Center; San Francisco Day School volunteer; and Harvard Schools Committee Interviewer for San Francisco.     Fran Schulz is an assurance partner at Ernst & Young in the Life Sciences Practice.  Her clients include both public life sciences companies and emerging private life sciences companies. Over the course of her career, she has played a key role in helping companies work through the details of collaboration agreements, corporate spin-offs, reorganizations, and mergers and acquisitions, and has had personal involvement in over fifty public stock offerings. Her extensive experience with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) stems from her work with numerous public companies. She is on the board of directors of Women in Bio and the California Life Sciences Association.  Her community service includes her role as a member of the Executive Leadership Team of American Heart Association Annual Research Roundtable.  She is also a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the California Society of CPAs, Women Business Leaders.  Fran Schulz is a 1985 Menlo College graduate.  Regarding the newly appointed trustees, Menlo Board Chair Micah Kane commented, “These two exceptionally well-qualified individuals bring a wealth of expertise in strategy, management, and audit.  In addition to their exceptional professional experience, they both also bring a strong passion to further the College’s mission. I look forward to working with them both on the Menlo College Board.”...
Menlo College Awarded Gold NAIA Five-Star Champions of Character Award

KANSAS CITY, Mo. – For the 11th consecutive year, Menlo College has been recognized as an NAIA Five-Star Champions of Character Institution, earning gold honors for the 2018-19 season. This marks the third time in the last five seasons Menlo Athletics has earned gold distinction (2014-15, 2016-17). Eight different Golden State Athletics Conference Institutions were named Champions of Character with six earning gold status. Overall, Menlo is among only 25% of NAIA institutions across the country to earn the distinction of gold Five-Star Champions of Character for the 2018-19 season.  Points are awarded through the Champions of Character Scorecard which measures growth in training, promotion, conduct in competition and commitment in five key areas with a possibility of earning 100 points. Institutions can be recognized as Champions of Character Five-Star Institutions at three different levels: Gold (90-100 points), Silver (75-89 points) and Bronze (60-74 points).  This year 180 NAIA institutions earned the Champions of Character Five-Star Institution Award.  The mission of the Champions of Character program is to help student-athletes and their coaches embody five core values: integrity, respect, responsibility, sportsmanship, and servant leadership.  Since the NAIA went to the bronze, silver and gold system, Menlo has three gold awards and three silver awards to its credit....

Business Entrepreneurship and Innovation Degree Program

Menlo College application deadlines are Early Action and Regular Decision. All required documents must be submitted by the deadline. Applications received after the Regular Decision deadline are subject to availability of space.
If you have missed the application deadline, please contact the admissions office immediately for advice.
By applying before the Early Action deadline:
The application fee will be waived.
You will receive a decision from Menlo College by mid-December.
You will have priority standing for scholarships.
FAFSA filers will have priority over all non-early action applicants in processing of their financial aid package by our Financial Aid Office (domestic first-year students only).
You will receive a decision from Menlo College by mid-April.
FAFSA filers will have priority over all non-early action applicants in processing of their financial aid package by our Financial Aid Office (domestic transfers only).

Business Entrepreneurship and Innovation Degree Program
Hours: Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. (excluding college holidays)
Welcome to Menlo College, the small college that gets the big picture!

The cutting-edge curriculum at Menlo College kicks off with a freshman Innovation Challenge, and culminates with a senior Capstone Project.  You will build your professional network through interactions with guest speakers in the classroom who represent today’s business rock stars.  Taking advantage of our proximity to San Francisco and San Jose and all points in between, you will visit top Silicon Valley companies, such as Google and Facebook. And you will garner job experience—and possibly a job offer—with our internship program. It’s the Menlo experience.
